resources.string: TalkBack may automatically expand the announcement for shortened characters and words, this can be confusing if the expansion doesn\'t match your intent:
An elegant fix is to include just a little bit more information:
TalkBack may announce strings of all capital letters one at a time rather than pronouncing the word:
Lower casing the string and setting it as the contentDescription (as below) allows the visual appearance of the text to stay the same, while allowing TalkBack to read it out more concisely:
Here is where you share a little bit about the APIs used to do the fix.
This layout should be used to include a basic failing example with a proper description.
This layout should be used to show a "fixed" example very similar to the one above.
This button has its own text, and its purpose is clear.
This button has no value for text or contentDescription. This makes it difficult for TalkBack users to understand it\'s purpose.

Note: Behaviors of this demo may vary widely based on Android, TalkBack, and Text-To-Speech engine version. If the user experience on your device is different, it is still an issue on other device combinations. All demos tested on Nexus 6 with Android 7.1.1, default TTS Engine and up to date TalkBack.
The below text does not display a proper color contrast ratio of 4.5:1.
The below text has a color contrast ratio between 4.5:1 and 3:1. This view requires manual testing.
EditText views must be tested manually. Hint Text is not importantForAccessibilty. Text in an EditText is importantForAccessibility.
The below text displays a proper color contrast ratio. The ratio is below 3:1 and is adequate for all text sizes.
This view must be tested manually because EditText views have specific requirements for color contrast.
This text color requires manual testing.
This text does not have a color contrast ratio of at least [3.0:1.0].
This text will pass the color contrast rule because it has a color contrast ratio of [4.5:1.0] or greater.
This text has a color contrast of between [3.0:1.0] and [4.5:1.0]. This text must be tested manually.

Adding hint text helps users determine what to enter in an EditText, but it and the contentDescription disappear once text is entered. That information is important to accessibility and does not return unless the EditText is cleared.
Correctly, this EditText has a label and no content description. Adding hint text can help users determine what to enter in the EditText.
Be sure to include descriptions of your FAILING/PASSING examples.
This ImageView is active (though it doesn\'t do anything), but does not have speakable text.
This ImageView has a content description.
The ImageView below presents important contextual information for the label next to it, but the image is not labeled, nor is it even focusable.
Here we have added a contentDescription, so TalkBack users can know that the cutie in question is in fact a puppy.
The ImageView below does not provide any additional context for the label next to it. Focusing the image and then focusing the label is just redundant:

By setting importantForAccessibility=yes on the layout, we get some awesome behavior for free. The image and its visible label are now bound together in one larger focusable container. We also have removed the contentDescription from the image, it is no longer required:
Here is an example of the best practice mentioned in the demo above. The parent has a listener in the activity.

The visible TextView with a labelFor=\"The Lights\" has been marked not important for accessibility. This means it is not accessibility focusable, which presents a confusing highlight for sighted TalkBack users.
The Lights label is focusable. A best practice would be to wrap the switch and visible label together into one layout that is active.
A view\'s label must have speakable text that is associated with the switch. In this case, there is visible text, but it is not associated with the switch by either the text or labelFor attribute.
The switch has no labelFor property to link it\'s label (The Lights), only its state (Off). This fails to identify the purpose of the switch to a non-sighted user.
Here we have associated the visible \'The Lights\' label with the Switch using the labelFor attribute.
Here we have given the switch a text attribute, which on the Android API defaults the text to the left and fills the space.
The above switch is properly labeled by an associated label using the Android labelFor attribute.
The above switch has a proper Android text attribute associated with the switch.
A parent that is accessibility focusable (by importantForAccessibility and/or focusable) but contains an active element can confuse a user.
A parent that is accessibility focusable (by importantForAccessibility and/or focusable) should not contain more than one active element.

The layout below is attempting to associate two views together. However, since one of them is active the simple \'importantForAccessibility=yes\' trick doesn\'t work. We end up with a focusable Switch nested inside a separately focusable layout. Very confusing for sighted TalkBack users.

In this case it is easiest just to let the views be individually focusable. Alternatively, we could wrap the Switch and TextView in a layout and share the state between the two. Either solution is acceptable, the former is implemented, the latter is a best practice.
A photo of a cute little puppy.
This switch does not have adequate touch target size. This is a Switch created from the GUI layout creater. It\'s default size is too small.
Independent Button (not nested in another element) that has adequate touch target size (48x48 CSS pixels).
This switch has the proper touch target size (minimum of 48x48 CSS pixels).
